<math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="A r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="K with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="C a with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>

The four species above have the same electron configuration, <math alttext="1 s 2, 2 s 2, 2 p 6, 3 s 2, 3 p 6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1</mn><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mn>2</mn><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mtext> </mtext><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following statements correctly identifies the species with the largest radius and provides an explanation based on Coulomb’s law?

choices.label: <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because its nuclear charge exerts the least attractive force on the electrons in the <math alttext="3 p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel.

<math alttext="A r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it is a neutral atom and the net force on the electrons in the <math alttext="3 p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel is zero.

<math alttext="K with a positive 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the loss of an electron results in a smaller attractive force between the nucleus and the electrons in the <math alttext="3 p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel.

<math alttext="C a with a positive 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the large positive charge on a cation causes increased repulsion among the electrons in the <math alttext="3 p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel.

content.answer: <math alttext="C l with a negative 1 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>C</mi><mi>l</mi></mrow></mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because its nuclear charge exerts the least attractive force on the electrons in the <math alttext="3 p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sublevel.
